turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Tell me, Baxter -- just what is it that makes you so popular?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Think.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Would you mind repeating the question?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Look, Baxter, I'm not stupid. I know everything that goes on in this building -- in every department -- on every floor -- every day of the year.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You do?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: In 1957, we had an employee here, name of Fowler. He was very popular, too. Turned out he was running a bookie joint right in the Actuarial Department tying up the switchboard, figuring the odds on our I.B.M. machines -- so the day before the Kentucky Derby, I called in the Vice Squad and we raided the thirteenth floor.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: The Vice Squad?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: That's right, Baxter.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What -- what's that got to do with me? I'm not running any bookie joint.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: What kind of joint are you running?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: There's a certain key floating around the office -- from Kirkeby to Vanderhof to Eichelberger to Dobisch -- it's the key to a certain apartment -- and you know who that apartment belongs to?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Loyal, cooperative, resourceful C. C. Baxter.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Are you going to deny it?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No, sir. I'm not going to deny it. But if you'd just let me explain --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You better.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, about six months ago -- I was going to night school, taking this course in Advanced Accounting -- and one of the guys in our department -- he lives in Jersey -- he was going to a banquet at the Biltmore -- his wife was meeting him in town, and he needed someplace to change into a tuxedo -- so I gave him the key    and word must have gotten around -- because the next thing I knew, all sorts of guys were suddenly going to banquets -- and when you give the key to one guy, you can't say no to another and the whole thing got out of hand -- pardon me.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Baxter, an insurance company is founded on public trust. Any employee who conducts himself in a manner unbecoming --  How many charter members are there in this little club of yours?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Just those four -- out of a total of 31,259 -- so actually, we can be very proud of our personnel -- percentage-wise.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: That's not the point. Four rotten apples in a barrel -- no matter how large the barrel -- you realize that if this ever leaked out --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, it won't. Believe me. And it's not going to happen again. From now on, nobody is going to use my apartment --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Where is your apartment?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: West 67th Street. You have no idea what I've been going through -- with the neighbors and the landlady and the liquor and the key --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: How do you work it with the key?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, usually I slip it to them in the office and they leave it under the mat -- but never again -- I can promise you that --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Where are you going, Baxter?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, I don't want to intrude -- and I thought -- since it's all straightened out anyway --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I'm not through with you yet.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: The reason I called is -- I won't be home for dinner tonight. The branch manager from Kansas City is in town -- I'm taking him to the theatre Music Man, what else? No, don't wait up for me -- 'bye, darling.  Tell me something,  Baxter  -- have you seen Music Man?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Not yet. But I hear it's one swell show.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: How would you like to go tonight?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You mean -- you and me? I thought you were taking the branch manager from Kansas City --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I made other plans. You can have both tickets.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, that's very kind of you -- only I'm not feeling well -- you see, I have this cold -- and I thought I'd go straight home.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Baxter, you're not reading me. I told you I have plans.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: So do I -- I'm going to take four aspirins and get into bed -- so you better give the tickets to somebody else --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I'm not just giving those tickets, Baxter -- I want to swap them.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Swap them? For what?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: It also says here -- that you are alert, astute, and quite imaginative --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh?  Oh!

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: This?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: That's good thinking, Baxter. Next month there's going to be a shift in personnel around here -- and as far as I'm concerned, you're executive material.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I am?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Now put down the key --  -- and put down the address.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh -- terribly sorry. It's that cold --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Relax, Baxter.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Now remember, Baxter -- this is going to be our little secret.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, of course.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You know how people talk.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, you don't have to worry --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Not that I have anything to hide.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, no sir. Certainly not. Anyway, it's none of my business -- four apples, five apples -- what's the difference -- percentage-wise?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Here you are, Baxter. Have a nice time.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You too, sir.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Morning, gentlemen.  Everything satisfactory? You like your office?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, yes, sir. Very much. And I want to thank you --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Don't thank me -- thank your friends here -- they're the ones who recommended you.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I like the way you handled that. Well, how does it feel to be an executive?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Fine. And I want you to know I'll work very hard to justify your confidence in me -- SHELDRAKE Sure you will.  Say, Baxter, about the apartment - now that you got a raise, don't you think we can afford a second key?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well -- I guess so.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You know my secretary -- Miss Olsen --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, yes. Very attractive. Is she -- the lucky one?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: No, you don't understand. She's a busybody -- always poking her nose into things -- and with that key passing back and forth -- why take chances?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, sir. You can't be too careful.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: To me?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I mean -- the young lady -- whoever she may be -- it was on the couch when I got home last night.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Oh, yes. Thanks.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: The mirror is broken.  It was broken when I found it.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: So it was.  She threw it at me.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You know how it is -- sooner or later they all give you a bad time.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I know how it is.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You see a girl a couple of times a week -- just for laughs -- and right away she thinks you're going to divorce your wife. I ask you -- is that fair?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No, sir. That's very unfair -- especially to your wife.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Yeah.  You know, Baxter, I envy you. Bachelor -- all the dames you want -- no headaches, no complications --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, sir. That's the life, all right.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Put me down for Thursday again.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Roger. And I'll get that other key.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Hello? -- yes -- what's on your mind, Baxter?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I hate to disturb you, but something came up -- it's rather important -- and I think it would be a good idea if you could see me -- at the apartment -- as soon as possible.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You're not making sense, Baxter. What's this all about?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I didn't want to tell you over the phone but that certain party -- you know who I mean -- I found her here last night -- she had taken an overdose of sleeping pills.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I thought maybe you'd like to be here when she wakes up.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: That's impossible.  You'll have to handle this situation yourself -- as a matter of fact, I'm counting on you --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, sir -- I understand.  She left a note -- you want me to open it and read it to you?  Well, it was just a suggestion -- no, you don't have to worry about that, Mr. Sheldrake -- I kept your name out of it so there'll be no trouble, police-wise or newspaper- wise --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, she's in the shower -- she's coming along fine, considering.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Good. Is there anything you need -- money -- ?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No, thank you, Mr. Sheldrake. As a matter of fact, I've got some money for you -- a hundred dollars --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Oh.  Well, if there's anything I can do for you --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: For me? I don't think so. But I was hoping maybe you could do something for her --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Like what? Put yourself in my place, Baxter -- how can I help her -- my hands are tied --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Mr. Sheldrake, I've got good news for you --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: And I've got good news for you, Baxter. All your troubles are over.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I know how worried you were about Miss Kubelik -- well, stop worrying -- I'm going to take her off your hands.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You're going to take her off my hands?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: That's right.  I've moved out of my house -- I'm going to be staying in town, at the Athletic Club.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You left your wife?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Well, if you must know -- I fired my secretary, my secretary got to my wife, and my wife fired me. Ain't that a kick in the head?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Now what was your news, Baxter?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It's about Miss Kubelik -- she's all right again -- so she went back home.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Swell. And don't think I've forgotten what you did for me.  This way, Baxter.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You like?  It's all yours.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Mine?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: My assistant, Roy Thompson, has been shifted to the Denver office, and you're taking his place.  What's the matter, Baxter? You don't seem very excited.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, it's just that so many things have been happening so fast -- I'm very pleased -- especially for Miss Kubelik. Now that I've gotten to know her better, I think she's the kind of girl that definitely ought to be married to somebody --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Oh, sure, sure. But first the property settlement has to be worked out -- then it takes six weeks in Reno -- meanwhile, I'm going to enjoy being a bachelor for a while.  Oh, by the way, you can now have lunch in the executive dining room --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: That's just one of the privileges that goes with this job. You also get a nice little expense account, the use of the executive washroom --  Say, what happened to you, Baxter?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I got kicked in the head, too.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Here's the breakdown of figures on personnel turnover. Thirty-seven percent of our female employees leave to get married, twenty-two percent quit because --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You're working too hard, Baxter. It's New Year's Eve -- relax.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I suppose you'll be on the town tonight -- celebrating?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Naturally.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Me, too. I'm taking Miss Kubelik out -- I finally talked her into it --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: The only thing is I'm staying at the Athletic Club -- and it's strictly stag so if you don't mind --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Don't mind what?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You know that other key to your apartment -- well, when we had that little scare about Miss Kubelik, I thought I'd better get rid of it quick -- so I threw it out the window of the commuter train.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Very clever.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Now I'll have to borrow your key.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sorry, Mr. Sheldrake.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: What do you mean, sorry?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You're not going to bring anybody up to my apartment.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I'm not just bringing anybody -- I'm bringing Miss Kubelik.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Especially not Miss Kubelik.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: How's that again?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No key!

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Baxter, I picked you for my team because I thought you were a bright young man. You realize what you're doing? Not to me -- but to yourself. Normally it takes years to work your way up to the twenty-seventh floor -- but it takes only thirty seconds to be out on the street again. You dig?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I dig.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: So what's it going to be?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Now you're being bright?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Say, Baxter -- you gave me the wrong key.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No I didn't.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: But this is the key to the executive washroom.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: That's right, Mr. Sheldrake. I won't be needing it -- because I'm all washed up around here.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: What's gotten into you, Baxter?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Just following doctor's orders. I've decided to become a mensch. You know what that means? A human being.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Now hold on, Baxter --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Save it. The old payola won't work any more. Goodbye, Mr. Sheldrake.

turns.speaker: MATUSCHKA
turns.text: Baxter?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: How do you do, Mr. Matuschka?

turns.speaker: MATUSCHKA
turns.text: Okay, get your clothes on. I got the cab downstairs.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Now, wait a minute. I know what you're thinking -- but it's not as bad as it looks -- MATUSCHKA  It's none of my business what you do, Fran -- you're over twenty- one -- but your sister happens to think you're a lady.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: All we were going to do is eat and wash the dishes --

turns.speaker: MATUSCHKA
turns.text: Look, Buddy-boy -- if there wasn't a lady present, I'd clobber you.

turns.speaker: MATUSCHKA
turns.text: What's the matter with Miss Kubelik?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, this is Mr. Matuschka -- he's Miss Kubelik's -- he's got a cab downstairs --

turns.speaker: MATUSCHKA
turns.text: Fran been sick or something?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No, no -- just had a little accident.

turns.speaker: MATUSCHKA
turns.text: What does he mean, accident?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: On account of me.

turns.speaker: MATUSCHKA
turns.text: You?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Who else?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Mr. Kirkeby, I don't like to complain -- but you were supposed to be out of here by eight.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: I know, Buddy-boy, I know.  But those things don't always run on schedule -- like a Greyhound bus.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I don't mind in the summer -- but on a rainy night -- and I haven't had any dinner yet --

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Sure, sure.  Look, kid -- I put in a good word for you with Sheldrake, in Personnel.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Mr. Sheldrake?

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: That's right.  We were discussing our department -- manpower-wise -- and promotion-wise --  -- and I told him what a bright boy you were.  They're always on the lookout for young executives. BUD Thank you, Mr. Kirkeby.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: You're on your way up, Buddy-boy. And you're practically out of liquor.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I know.  Mr. Eichelberger -- in the Mortgage Loan Department -- last night he had a little Halloween party here --

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Well, lay in some vodka and some vermouth -- and put my name on it.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Kirkeby.  You still owe me for the last two bottles --

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: I'll pay you on Friday.  And whatever happened to those little cheese crackers you used to have around?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Good morning, Mr. Kirkeby.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Oh, how are you, Baxter.  They keeping you busy these days?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, sir.  They are indeed.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: That Kubelik -- boy!  Would I like to get her on a slow elevator to China.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, yes.  She's the best operator in the building.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: I'm a pretty good operator myself -- but she just won't give me a tumble -- date-wise.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Maybe you're using the wrong approach.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: A lot of guys around here have tried it -- all kinds of approaches -- no dice.  What is she trying to prove?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Could be she's just a nice, respectable girl -- there are millions of them.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Listen to him.  Little Lord Fauntleroy!

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Hello? Yeah, Baxter. What's up?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Instead of Friday -- could you possibly switch to Thursday? You'd be doing me a great favor --

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Well -- it's all right with me, Bud. Let me check. I'll get back to you.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Baxter, we're a little disappointed in you -- gratitude-wise.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, I'm very grateful.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: So long, Baxter. We know you won't let us down.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: So long, fellas. Drop in any time. The door is always open -- to my office.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Hi, Baxter.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: What do I -- ?  Just a minute.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You can't come in.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: What's the matter with you, Buddy- boy? I made a reservation for four o'clock, remember?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Look, you can't stay here. Just take your champagne and go.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Baxter, I don't want to pull rank on you -- but I told the lady it was all set -- you want to make a liar out of me?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Are you going to leave, Mr. Kirkeby, or do I have to throw you out?

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Buddy-boy, why didn't you say so?  You got yourself a little playmate, huh?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Now will you get out?

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Say, why don't we have ourselves a party -- the four of us?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Hiya, Buddy-boy.  I'm in this bar on Sixty-first Street -- and I got to thinking about you -- and I figured I'd give you a little buzz.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, that's very nice of you -- but who is this?

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Dobisch -- Joe Dobisch, in Administration.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, yes, Mr. Dobisch.  I didn't recognize your voice --

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: That's okay, Buddy-boy.  Now like I was saying, I'm in this joint on Sixty-first -- and I think I got lucky --  -- she's a skater with the Ice Show --  -- and I thought maybe I could bring her up for a quiet drink.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Dobisch.  You know I like to help you guys out -- but it's sort of late -- so why don't we make it some other time?

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Buddy-boy -- she won't keep that long -- not even on ice.  Listen, kid, I can't pass this up -- she looks like Marilyn Monroe.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I don't care if it is Marilyn Monroe -- I'm already in bed -- and I've taken a sleeping pill -- so I'm afraid the answer is no.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Look, Baxter -- we're making out the monthly efficiency rating -- and I'm putting you in the top ten. Now you don't want to louse yourself up, do you?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Of course not.  But -- how can I be efficient in the office if I don't get enough sleep at night?

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: It's only eleven -- and I just want the place for forty-five minutes.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Make it thirty minutes.  What do you say, Bud?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm all out of liquor -- and there's no clean glasses -- no cheese crackers -- no nothing.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Let me worry about that.  Just leave the key under the mat and clear out.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Dobisch.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Oh, Buddy-boy. I was just about to call you.  I'm sorry about that mess on the living room wall. You see, my little friend, she kept insisting Picasso was a bum -- so she started to do that mural -- but I'm sure it will wash off -- just eyebrow pencil.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It's not Picasso I'm calling about. It's the key -- to my apartment -- you were supposed to leave it under the mat.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: I did, didn't I? I distinctly remember bending over and putting it there --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, I found a key there, all right -- only it's the wrong key.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: It is?  Well, how about that? No wonder I couldn't get into the executive washroom this morning.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: And I couldn't get into my apartment -- so at four a. m. I had to wake up the landlady and give her a whole song and dance about going out to mail a letter and the door slamming shut.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: That's a shame. I'll send the key right down. And about your promotion --  -- I'm sending that efficiency report right up to Mr. Sheldrake, in Personnel. I wouldn't be surprised if you heard from him before the day is over.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Thank you, Mr. Dobisch.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Teamwork -- that's what counts in an organization like this. All for one and one for all -- know what I mean?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I have a vague idea.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: We went to bat for you -- and now you won't play ball with us.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, after all, it's my apartment -- it's private property -- it's not a public playground.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I sympathize with your problem -- and believe me, I'm very sorry --

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: You'll be a lot sorrier before we're through with you.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You threatening me?

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Listen, Baxter, we made you and we can break you.

turns.speaker: VANDERHOF
turns.text: Dear Mr. MacIntosh --  Vanderhof, Public Relations. Oh, yes, Baxter. Just a minute.  All right, Miss Finch -- type up what we got so far.  Now what is it, Baxter?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Look, Mr. Vanderhof -- I've got you down here for tonight -- but I'm going to be using the place myself -- so I'll have to cancel.

turns.speaker: VANDERHOF
turns.text: Cancel? But it's her birthday -- I already ordered the cake --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I hate to disappoint you -- I mean, many happy returns -- but not tonight --

turns.speaker: VANDERHOF
turns.text: That's not like you, Baxter. Just the other day, at the staff meeting, I was telling Mr. Sheldrake what a reliable man you were.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Thank you, Mr. Vanderhof. But I'm sick -- I have this terrible cold -- and a fever -- and I got to go to bed right after work.

turns.speaker: VANDERHOF
turns.text: Buddy-boy, that's the worst thing you can do. If you got a cold, you should go to a Turkish bath -- spend the night there -- sweat it out --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, no. I'd get pneumonia -- and if I got pneumonia, I'd be in bed for a month -- and if I were in bed for a month --

turns.speaker: VANDERHOF
turns.text: Okay, you made your point. We'll just have to do it next Wednesday -- that's the only night of the week I can get away.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Wednesday -- Wednesday --  I got somebody penciled in -- let me see what I can do -- I'll get back to you.

turns.speaker: VANDERHOF
turns.text: Quite an office -- name on the door -- rug on the floor -- the whole schmear.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Good evening, Baxter.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Hi, Doc.  Had a late call?

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Yeah.  Some clown at Schrafft's 57th Street ate a club sandwich, and forgot to take out the toothpick.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh.  'Bye, Doc.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Say, Baxter -- the way you're belting that stuff, you must have a pair of cast-iron kidneys.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, that's not me.  It's just that once in a while, I have some people in for a drink.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: As a matter of fact, you must be an iron man all around. From what I hear through the walls, you got something going for you every night.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm sorry if it gets noisy --

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Sometimes,  there's a twi-night double-header.  A nebbish like you!

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah.  Well -- see you, Doc.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: You know, Baxter -- I'm doing some research at the Columbia Medical Center -- and I wonder if you could do us a favor?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: When you make out your will -- and the way you're going, you should -- would you mind leaving your body to the University?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: My body?  I'm afraid you guys would be disappointed.  Good night, Doc.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Slow down, kid.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: There's a girl in my place -- she took some sleeping pills -- you better come quick -- I can't wake her up.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Let me get my bag.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: She going to be all right, Doc?

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: How many pills were in that bottle?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It was half-full -- about a dozen or so. You going to have to take her to the hospital?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What are you going to do, Doc?

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Get that stuff out of her stomach -- if it isn't too late. You better put some coffee on -- and pray.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Want to tell me what happened?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I don't know -- I mean -- I wasn't here -- you see -- we had some words earlier -- nothing serious, really -- what you might call a lovers' quarrel --

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: So you went right out and picked yourself up another dame.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Something like that.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: You know, Baxter, you're a real cutie-pie -- yes, you are.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: What's her name?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Miss Kubelik -- Fran.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Fran, I'm a doctor. I'm here because you took too many sleeping pills. Do you understand what I'm saying?  Fran, I'm Dr. Dreyfuss -- I'm here to help you. You took all those sleeping pills -- remember?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Hello, Miss Kubelik.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Mister -- Miss -- such politeness!

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well -- we work in the same building -- and we try to keep it quiet --

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: She'll sleep on and off for the next twenty-four hours. Of course, she'll have a dandy hangover when she wakes up --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Just as long as she's okay.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: These cases are harder on the doctor than on the patient. I ought to charge you by the mile.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Any of that coffee left?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: How do you spell her last name?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Kubelik -- with two k's.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: What's her address?  Where does she live?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Why do you want to know, Doc? You don't have to report this, do you?

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: It's regulations.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: She didn't mean it, Doc -- it was an accident -- she had a little too much to drink and -- she didn't know what she was doing -- there was no suicide note or anything -- believe me, Doc, I'm not thinking about myself --

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Aren't you?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It's just that she's got a family -- and there's the people in the office -- look, Doc, can't you forget you're a doctor -- let's just say you're here as a neighbor --

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Well, as a doctor, I guess I can't prove it wasn't an accident.  But as your neighbor, I'd like to kick your keester clear around the block.  Mind if I cool this off?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Help yourself.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: I don't know what you did to that girl in there -- and don't tell me -- but it was bound to happen, the way you carry on. Live now, pay later. Diner's Club!  Why don't you grow up, Baxter? Be a mensch! You know what that means?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I'm not sure.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: A mansch -- a human being! So you got off easy this time -- so you were lucky --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah, wasn't I?

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: But you're not out of the woods yet, Baxter -- because most of them try it again!  You know where I am if you need me.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: How's the patient?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh, I'm fine, Doc.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Not you -- Miss Kubelik.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Say, Baxter -- we're having a little party and we ran out of ice -- so I was wondering --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Sure, Doc.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: How come you're alone on New Year's Eve?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, I have things to do --

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: What's this -- you packing?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Yeah -- I'm giving up the apartment.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Where are you moving to?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I don't know. All I know is I got to get out of this place.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Sorry to lose you, Baxter.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Me? Oh, you mean my body. Don't worry, Doc -- it'll go to the University -- I'll put it in writing --

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Can you use a bottle of champagne?

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Booze we don't need. Why don't you join us, Baxter? We got two brain surgeons, an ear, nose and throat specialist, a proctologist, and three nurses from Bellevue.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No, thanks -- I don't feel like it. Look, Doc -- in case I don't see you again -- how much do I owe you for taking care of that girl?

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Forget it -- I didn't do it as a doctor -- I did it as a neighbor.  By the way, whatever happened to her?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: You know me with girls. Easy come, easy go. Goodbye, Doc.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Happy New Year.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: You like Castro?  I mean -- how do you feel about Castro? BUD What is Castro?

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: You know, that big-shot down in Cuba with the crazy beard.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: What about him?

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Because as far as I'm concerned, he's a no good fink. Two weeks ago I wrote him a letter -- never even answered me.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: That so.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: All I wanted him to do was let Mickey out for Christmas.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Who is Mickey?

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: My husband. He's in Havana -- in jail.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Oh. Mixed up in that revolution?

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Mickey? He wouldn't do nothing like that. He's a jockey. They caught him doping a horse.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, you can't win 'em all.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: 'Twas the night before Christmas And all through the house Not a creature was stirring -- Nothing -- No action -- Dullsville!  You married?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Family?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: A night like this, it sort of spooks you to walk into an empty apartment.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: I said I had no family -- I didn't say I had an empty apartment.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Where do we go -- my place or yours?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Might as well go to mine -- everybody else does.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Poor Mickey -- when I think of him all by himself in that jail in Havana --  -- want to see his picture?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Not particularly.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Can I ask you a personal question?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: You got a girl-friend?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: She may be a girl -- but she's no friend of mine.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Still stuck on her, huh.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Stuck on her! Obviously, you don't know me very well.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: I don't know you at all. BUD Permit me -- C.C. Baxter -- junior executive, Arthur Murray graduate, lover.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Say, this is Snugsville.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Mrs. MacDougall, I think it is only fair to warn you that you are now alone with a notorious sexpot.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: No kidding.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Ask anybody around here. As a matter of fact, when it's time for me to go -- and I may go just like that --  -- I have promised my body to the Columbia Medical Center.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Gee. Sort of gives you goose-bumps just to think about it.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Well, they haven't got me yet, baby. Dig up some ice from the kitchen and let's not waste any time -- preliminary-wise.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: I'm with you, lover.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Not so rough, honey.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Good night?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: The party's over.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: What's the matter? Did I do something wrong?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: It's an emergency -- see you some other time.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: Say, what's going on here, anyway?

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Nothing.  Just clear out, will you?

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: My shoes.

turns.speaker: BUD
turns.text: Here -- find yourself a phone booth and call your husband in Havana.

turns.speaker: MARGIE
turns.text: You bet I will. And when I tell him how you treated me, he'll push your face in.  You fink!

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: -- so yesterday afternoon I take Sylvia up to the apartment, and guess who he's got stashed away in the bedroom?

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Kubelik.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: No kidding. Buddy-boy and Kubelik having themselves a little toot!

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Toot? It's more like a lost weekend. Neither of them showed up for work today.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: A.W.O.L.?

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: What gripes me is the two of them were guzzling my champagne while Sylvia and I wound up at the Guggenheim Museum.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: I see.  What do you think, Al? Can we help the man?

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Why not? We don't owe Buddy-boy anything.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Yeah. What's Buddy-boy done for us lately?

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Hi, Buddy-boy. What happened to you?

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Hit by a swinging door? Or maybe a Yellow Cab?

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: That guy really must've belted him.

turns.speaker: DOBISCH
turns.text: Yeah, he's punchy. Talking to himself.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Sleeping pills.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: That's right, Fran. And I'm a doctor.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Doctor.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Dr. Dreyfuss.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Dreyfuss.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Get more coffee.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Tell me again -- what's my name?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Dr. Dreyfuss.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: And what happened to you?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I took sleeping pills.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Do you know where you are, Fran?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Yes, you do. Now concentrate.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: Do you know who this is?  Look at him.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Mr. Baxter -- nineteenth floor.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Please -- just let me sleep.

turns.speaker: DR. DREYFUSS
turns.text: You can't sleep.  Come on, Fran -- open your eyes.  Let's get her walking. We've got to keep her awake for the next couple of hours.

turns.speaker: MATUSCHKA
turns.text: What's with you, Fran -- did you forget where you live?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: This is my brother-in-law, Karl Matuschka.

turns.speaker: MATUSCHKA
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Because I took some sleeping pills. But I'm all right now -- so let's go.

turns.speaker: MATUSCHKA
turns.text: Why did you take sleeping pills?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You fool -- you damn fool.

turns.speaker: MATUSCHKA
turns.text: Come on, Fran.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Goodbye, Mr. Baxter.

turns.speaker: MISS OLSEN
turns.text: Hi. How's the branch manager from Kansas City?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I beg your pardon? MISS OLSEN I'm Miss Olsen -- Mr. Sheldrake's secretary.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Yes, I know.

turns.speaker: MISS OLSEN
turns.text: So you don't have to play innocent with me. He used to tell his wife that I was the branch manager from Seattle -- four years ago when we were having a little ring-a-ding- ding.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: MISS OLSEN
turns.text: And before me there was Miss Rossi in Auditing -- and after me there was Miss Koch in Disability -- and just before you there was Miss What's-Her-Name, on the twenty- fifth floor --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Will you excuse me?

turns.speaker: MISS OLSEN
turns.text: What for? You haven't done anything -- it's him -- what a salesman -- always the last booth in the Chinese restaurant -- and the same pitch about divorcing his wife -- and in the end you wind up with egg foo yong on your face.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Well -- thank you.

turns.speaker: MISS OLSEN
turns.text: Always happy to do something for our girls in uniform.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Still afraid somebody may see us together?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Let me take that.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: No, Jeff. I can't stay very long.  Can I have a frozen daiquiri?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: It's on the way.  I see you went ahead and cut your hair.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You know I liked it better long.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Yes, I know. You want a lock to carry in your wallet?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: How long has it been -- a month?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Six weeks. But who's counting?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I missed you, Fran.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Like old times. Same booth, same song --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: It's been hell.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: -- same sauce -- sweet and sour.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You don't know what it's like -- standing next to you in that elevator, day after day -- Good morning, Miss Kubelik -- Good night, Mr. Sheldrake -- I'm still crazy about you, Fran.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Let's not start on that again, Jeff -- please. I'm just beginning to get over it.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I don't believe you.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Look, Jeff -- we had two wonderful months this summer -- and that was it. Happens all the time -- the wife and kids go away to the country, and the boss has a fling with the secretary or the manicurist -- or the elevator girl. Comes September, the picnic is over -- goodbye. The kids go back to school, the boss goes back to the wife, and the girl --  They don't make these shrimp like they used to.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I never said goodbye, Fran.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: For a while there, you try kidding yourself that you're going with an unmarried man. Then one day he keeps looking at his watch, and asks you if there's any lipstick showing, then rushes off to catch the seven-fourteen to White Plains. So you fix yourself a cup of instant coffee -- and you sit there by yourself -- and you think -- and it all begins to look so ugly --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: How do you think I felt -- riding home on that seven-fourteen train?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Why do you keep calling me, Jeff? What do you want from me?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I want you back, Fran.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Sorry, Mr. Sheldrake -- I'm full up. You'll have to take the next elevator.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You're not giving me a chance, Fran. I asked you to meet me because -- I have something to tell you. FRAN Go ahead -- tell me.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Not here, Fran. Can't we go some place else?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: No. I have a date at eight-thirty.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Important?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Not very -- but I'm going to be there anyway.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Fran -- remember that last weekend we had?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Do I. That leaky little boat you rented -- and me in a black negligee and a life preserver --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Remember what we talked about?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: We talked about a lot of things.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I mean -- about my getting a divorce.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: We didn't talk about it -- you did.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You didn't really believe me, did you?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: They got it an a long playing record now - Music to String Her Along By. My wife doesn't understand me -- We haven't gotten along for years -- You're the best thing that ever happened to me --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: That's enough, Fran.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Just trust me, baby -- we'll work it out somehow --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: You're not being funny.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I wasn't trying.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: If you'll just listen to me for a minute --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Okay. I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I saw my lawyer this morning -- I wanted his advice  -- about the best way to handle it --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Handle what?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Let's get something straight, Jeff -- I never asked you to leave your wife.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Of course not. You had nothing to do with it.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Are you sure that's what you want?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I'm sure. If you'll just tell me that you still love me --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You know I do.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Fran --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I have that date -- remember?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I love you -- remember?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Where are we going, Jeff? Not back to that leaky boat --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I promise.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Come on, Fran -- don't be like that. You just going to sit there and keep bawling?  You won't talk to me, you won't tell me what's wrong --  Look, I know you think I'm stalling you. But when you've been married to a woman for twelve years, you don't just sit down at the breakfast table and say "Pass the sugar -- and I want a divorce." It's not that easy.  Anyway, this is the wrong time. The kids are home from school -- my in- laws are visiting for the holidays -- I can't bring it up now.  This isn't like you, Fran -- you were always such a good sport -- such fun to be with --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Yeah -- that's me. The Happy Idiot -- a million laughs.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Well, that's more like it. At least you're speaking to me.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Funny thing happened to me at the office party today -- I ran into your secretary -- Miss Olsen. You know -- ring-a-ding-ding? I laughed so much I like to died.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Is that what's been bothering you -- Miss Olsen? That's ancient history.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I was never very good at history. Let me see -- there was Miss Olsen, and then there was Miss Rossi -- no, she came before -- it was Miss Koch who came after Miss Olsen --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Now, Fran --

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: And just think -- right now there's some lucky girl in the building who's going to come after me --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Okay, okay, Fran. I deserve that. But just ask yourself -- why does a man run around with a lot of girls? Because he's unhappy at home -- because he's lonely, that's why -- all that was before you, Fran -- I've stopped running.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: How could I be so stupid? You'd think I would have learned by now -- when you're in love with a married man, you shouldn't wear mascara.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: It's Christmas Eve, Fran -- let's not fight.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Merry Christmas.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Oh. Our friend from the Chinese restaurant. Thanks, Fran. We better keep it here.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Yeah, we better.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I have a present for you. I didn't quite know what to get you -- anyway it's a little awkward for me, shopping --  -- so here's a hundred dollars -- go out and buy yourself something.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Okay.  I just thought as long as it was paid for --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Don't ever talk like that, Fran! Don't make yourself out to be cheap.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: A hundred dollars? I wouldn't call that cheap. And you must be paying somebody something for the use of the apartment --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Stop that, Fran.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You'll miss your train, Jeff.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Coming?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: You run along -- I want to fix my face.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Don't forget to kill the lights. See you Monday.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Sure. Monday and Thursday -- and Monday again -- and Thursday again --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: It won't always be like this.  I love you, Fran.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Hello, Jeff.  Yes, I'm all right.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Fran, why did you do it? It's so childish -- and it never solves anything -- I ought to be very angry with you, scaring me like that -- but let's forget the whole thing -- pretend it never happened -- what do you say, Fran?  Fran --

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Are you there, Fran?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Of course I'm not here -- because the whole thing never happened -- I never took those pills -- I never loved you -- we never even met -- isn't that the way you want it?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: There you go again -- you know I didn't mean it that way, Fran. Just get well -- do what the nurse tells you -- I mean Baxter -- and I'll see you as soon as I can. Bye, Fran.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Sorry it took me so long on the phone. But we're all set.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: All set for what?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I rented a car -- it's going to be here at one o'clock -- we're driving to Atlantic City.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Atlantic City?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I know it's a drag -- but you can't find a hotel room in town -- not on New Year's Eve.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Ring out the old year, ring in the new. Ring-a-ding-ding.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: I didn't plan it this way, Fran -- actually, it's all Baxter's fault.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: Baxter?

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: He wouldn't give me the key to the apartment.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: He wouldn't.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: Just walked out on me -- quit -- threw that big fat job right in my face.

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: The nerve.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: That little punk -- after all I did for him! He said I couldn't bring anybody to his apartment -- especially not Miss Kubelik. What's he got against you, anyway?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I don't know. I guess that's the way it crumbles -- cookie-wise.

turns.speaker: SHELDRAKE
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: FRAN
turns.text: I'd spell it out for you -- only I can't spell.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Please, Sylvia!  It's a quarter to nine!

turns.speaker: SYLVIA
turns.text: First you can't wait to get me up here, and now -- rush, rush, rush! Makes a person feel cheap.

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: Sylvia -- sweetie -- it's not that -- but I promised the guy I'd be out of here by eight o'clock, positively.

turns.speaker: SYLVIA
turns.text: What guy?  Whose apartment is this, anyway?

turns.speaker: KIRKEBY
turns.text: What's the difference?  Some schnook that works in the office.
